gen.metadata.title: Compact and High Gain 4 × 4 Circularly Polarized Microstrip Patch Antenna Array for Next Generation Small Satellite
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design, simulate, and fabricate a compact wideband CP microstrip antenna array for next-generation small satellite applications in the Ku-band (p. 7)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a gain of 12 dBic with minimal AR less than 1.5 dB in the angular width of ±10° (p. 9); Achieve a left-handed circularly polarized gain of more than 12 dBic with an axial ratio level below 1.5 dB in the ±10° angular space for the whole bandwidth from 8.05 GHz to 8.25 GHz (p. 1); Not mentioned; Extend the 2 × 2 array to a 4 × 4 array using a multistage SR feeding network (p. 9); Ensure the array meets the application requirements of next-generation small satellites (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of the array's performance in different environmental conditions (p. 1); Not mentioned; Development of multi-band CP microstrip antenna arrays (p. 10); Investigation of the design for other frequency bands (p. 10)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; Further testing and validation in real-world satellite applications (p. 10); Further testing and optimization for different satellite applications (p. 1); Optimization of the feeding network for higher efficiency (p. 10)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Limited availability of compact, high-gain, and wideband CP microstrip antenna arrays for next-generation small satellite applications (p. 7)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a high gain and compact 4 × 4 circularly polarized microstrip patch antenna array be designed for small satellites? (p. 1); What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna array in terms of gain, bandwidth, and axial ratio? (p. 1); How can a compact wideband CP microstrip antenna array be designed for small satellite applications? (p. 7); Not mentioned; What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna array compared to existing designs? (p. 7)
esp.domain_results.axial_ratio_bandwidth: 3 dB ARBW from 8.05 GHz to 8.25 GHz (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms other designs in terms of gain, AR, and compactness (p. 9)
esp.domain_results.cross_polarization_le: Below −15 dBic in the broadside direction (p. 9)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Stable in both φ = 0° and φ = 90° planes (p. 9)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: 4 × 4 circularly polarized microstrip patch antenna array (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Sequential rotational phase feed with open stub (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: Multiband circularly polarised CubeSat antenna operating in S, C, X, Ku, K, and Ka bands
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a high-frequency multiband circularly polarized antenna for CubeSat applications that can cover L, S, C, X, Ku, K, and Ka bands (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Evaluate the antenna's performance across multiple frequency bands (p. 5); Not mentioned; Maintain a compact size and weight to meet CubeSat standards (p. 1); Ensure the antenna fits within the standard 10 × 10 cm² size of a CubeSat (p. 1); Achieve wide and multiband operation with circular polarization (p. 1); Optimize the antenna design for circular polarization (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Explore the integration of additional features to enhance performance (p. 1); Not mentioned; Investigate the impact of environmental factors on antenna performance (p. 1); Investigate the impact of environmental factors on antenna performance (p. 11); Explore the integration of the antenna with other CubeSat systems (p. 11)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Conduct further testing and validation in real-world CubeSat missions (p. 1); Not mentioned; Integrate the proposed antenna design into CubeSat telecommunication subsystems (p. 1); Further optimize the design for specific CubeSat missions (p. 11); Test the antenna in space-like environments (p. 11)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing a high-frequency multiband circularly polarized antenna for CubeSat applications that can cover a wide range of frequency bands while maintaining compact size and weight (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a multiband circularly polarized antenna be designed to fit within the limited space of a CubeSat? (p. 1); What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna in terms of gain, bandwidth, and axial ratio? (p. 1); How does the hybrid design perform across multiple frequency bands? (p. 5); Not mentioned; What are the key design parameters for achieving circular polarization? (p. 5)
esp.domain_results.bandwidth: 1.5–2.9 GHz for the patch antenna, 4–31 GHz for the spiral antenna (p. 8)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The proposed antenna achieves good performance across multiple frequency bands and circular polarization, but may not achieve the same performance as larger, non-planar designs (p. 10)
esp.domain_results.gain: 7.09 dBi at 2 GHz, 7.38 dBi at 2.3 GHz, 7.89 dBi at 7.5 GHz, 8.1 dBi at 10 GHz, 8.41 dBi at 20 GHz, 9.1 dBi at 25 GHz, 9.81 dBi at 29 GHz (p. 13)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_dim: Ls = 100 mm, Ws = 100 mm, hs = 1.6 mm (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Four-patch antenna with 90° phase differences between ports (p. 6)
esp.technical_specifications.frequency_b: L-band (1.55–1.94 GHz), S-band (2, 2.1, 2.3 GHz), C-band (4–8 GHz), X-band (8–12 GHz), Ku-band (12–18 GHz), K-band (18–26 GHz), Ka-band (26–29 GHz) (p. 8)

gen.metadata.title: A Microstrip Antenna Based on a Standing-Wave Fractal Geometry for CubeSat Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a frequency reconfigurable E-shaped patch antenna using PIN diodes for operation in multiple frequency bands suitable for WMTS and MICS (p. 2214)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Reconfigure the antenna to operate in a narrow band centered at 0.5 GHz (p. 2214); Achieve dual-band operation at 0.4 and 1.4 GHz (p. 2214); Achieve triple-band operation at 0.4, 1.4, and 2 GHz (p. 2214); Achieve circular polarization and directional radiation (p. 2210); Maintain small dimensions and low weight (p. 2210)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate further miniaturization techniques (p. 2213); Investigate the performance of the antenna in real-world medical applications (p. 2214)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the proposed antenna for CubeSat applications (p. 2213); Use the proposed antenna in WMTS and MICS devices (p. 2214)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for compact, reconfigurable antennas for Wireless Medical Telemetry Systems (WMTS) and Medical Implant Communication Services (MICS) that can operate in multiple frequency bands (p. 2214)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a reconfigurable E-shaped patch antenna be designed to operate in multiple frequency bands for WMTS and MICS? (p. 2214); How can a planar antenna with circular polarization and reduced dimensions be designed for CubeSat applications? (p. 2210)
esp.domain_results.bandwidth: 335–565 MHz, 1.29–1.42 GHz, and 2.03–2.28 GHz in multiband; 300–645 MHz in single band (p. 2214)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Directional radiation with maximum radiation over the top face (H-plane) (p. 2212)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: FR4 epoxy dielectric substrate (εr = 4.4, tan δ = 0.003, h = 1.6 mm) (p. 2214)
esp.technical_specifications.frequency_b: 335–565 MHz, 1.29–1.42 GHz, and 2.03–2.28 GHz in multiband; 300–645 MHz in single band (p. 2214)

gen.metadata.title: Semi-analytical design of dual-mode resonant microstrip antennas with electrically small patch size and tilted CP angle for satellite-assisted IoV
gen.objectives.main_objective: To develop a semi-analytical design approach for dual-mode resonant microstrip antennas with electrically small patch size and tilted CP angle for satellite-assisted IoV (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Determine the upper bound of patch radius for electrically small antennas (p. 3); Deduce mathematical formulas to predict the flare angle and outer/inner radius ratio for approaching an electrically small radius (p. 1); Not mentioned; Design and validate dual-mode resonant microstrip antennas with different flare angles and substrates (p. 1); Design and validate dual-mode resonant MASPAs with variable CP angles (p. 3)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of the antenna's performance in different vehicular communication scenarios (p. 2); Not mentioned; Explore the application of the design approach to other frequency bands and substrates (p. 9)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; Further experimental validation of the antenna design in real-world IoV scenarios (p. 2); Use the semi-analytical design approach to design microstrip antennas for satellite applications (p. 9)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Limited understanding of how to design microstrip antennas with electrically small patch size and frequency scannable tilted CP angle for satellite-assisted IoV (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: Not mentioned; What are the performance metrics and practical applications of such antennas? (p. 1); How can a semi-analytical design approach be developed for dual-mode resonant microstrip antennas with electrically small patch size and tilted CP angle? (p. 1); How can electrically small, dual-mode resonant, wideband CP microstrip antennas be designed for IoV applications? (p. 2); What are the key parameters and methods for achieving variable CP angles in these antennas? (p. 2)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: Satimo’s Starlab near-field antenna measurement system (p. 6)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: MATLAB for eigen-root calculations, numerical simulation software (p. 3-4)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Compared to other reported tilted CP antennas, the proposed antennas exhibit a distinctive operation principle, wider tilted CP bandwidth, and larger tilted CP angle range with frequency scanning functionality (p. 9)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Tilted CP frequency scanning characteristic within the whole impedance bandwidth (p. 9)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: F4B substrate (ε_r1 = 2.65) with h_1 = 2 mm suspending on an air substrate (ε_r = 1) with h_2 = 3 mm (p. 7)

gen.metadata.title: A Multi-Band Circularly Polarized-Shared Aperture Antenna for Space Applications at S and X Bands
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and analyze a compact multiband antenna that shares the aperture of an S-band slot antenna to accommodate an X-band patch antenna for CubeSat applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve high gain and maintain circular polarization over a wideband (p. 1); Not mentioned; Replace two separate antennas with a single shared aperture antenna to save space (p. 1); Achieve high gain and compact size (p. 9); Ensure good isolation between S-band and X-band patches (p. 9)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Not mentioned; Investigate the performance of the antenna in different CubeSat configurations and environments (p. 1); Investigate the performance of the antenna in real CubeSat missions (p. 9)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; Use the proposed antenna for CubeSat applications to reduce size and complexity (p. 9); Integrate the shared aperture antenna design in CubeSat missions to optimize space and improve communication efficiency (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing a compact dual-band shared aperture antenna for CubeSat applications to reduce the size and complexity of antenna systems (p. 9)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a shared aperture antenna be designed to operate in both S-band and X-band for CubeSat applications? (p. 9); How can a single antenna design accommodate both S-band and X-band operations for CubeSats? (p. 1); Not mentioned; What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna compared to existing designs? (p. 9); What are the performance metrics of a shared aperture antenna in terms of gain, bandwidth, and circular polarization? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Finite element method (FEM) using Ansys HFSS 2022 (p. 5)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Achieved similar or better performances while keeping the antenna size compact compared to other recent works (p. 9)
esp.domain_results.return_loss: S-band: −30 dB (simulated), −16 dB (measured), X-band: −210 dB (simulated), −270 dB (measured) (p. 6, p. 8)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Shared aperture antenna with S-band and X-band patches (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Two separate 50Ω coaxial probes for S-band and X-band patches (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.superstrate: Dielectric layer-3 acts as a partial reflective surface (PRS) (p. 3)

gen.metadata.title: Design, Fabrication and Measurements of an X-Band Cross-Patch Antenna with Metasurface for Advanced LEO CubeSat Missions
gen.objectives.main_objective: To develop a miniaturized and optimized metasurface antenna for CubeSats that meets the requirements of minimal aerodynamic drag, extended mission duration, and efficient power consumption (p. 10)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Design and optimize a planar crossed dipole antenna using HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 2); Ensure the antenna does not require deployment mechanisms after launch (p. 10); Improve antenna performance using metasurface to increase CubeSat lifetime and data throughput (p. 2); Evaluate the fabricated antenna prototypes through measurements and compare them to simulation results (p. 2); Evaluate the antenna's performance in terms of gain, bandwidth, and radiation pattern (p. 5); Optimize the metasurface unit cell to enhance antenna performance (p. 10); Optimize the antenna design to minimize size and power consumption while maximizing performance (p. 5); Design a cross-patch antenna with a metasurface to achieve high gain and wide bandwidth (p. 10)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the metasurface antenna in different environmental conditions (p. 8); Explore the application of the antenna design in other frequency bands (p. 10); Investigate the performance of the antenna in different orbital conditions and with varying CubeSat configurations (p. 2); Develop multilayer Fabry-Perot antennas to achieve even higher gains (p. 10); Explore the use of advanced materials to further enhance antenna performance (p. 8)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Conduct further testing to optimize the design for different CubeSat sizes and missions (p. 8); Integrate the proposed antenna design into 1U CubeSat missions to enhance communication and mission longevity (p. 1); Integrate the developed antenna design into CubeSat missions to enhance communication capabilities (p. 10); Integrate the metasurface antenna design into CubeSat missions to improve communication efficiency (p. 8); Optimize the metasurface unit cell for further performance improvements (p. 10)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a compact, lightweight, and efficient antenna design for CubeSats to extend mission duration and improve data reception periods while maintaining low power consumption (p. 10)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What are the key performance metrics that can be achieved with the new antenna design? (p. 10); What are the performance improvements of the metasurface antenna compared to traditional designs? (p. 5); How can the antenna design be optimized to meet the geometrical, mechanical, and electrical requirements of CubeSats? (p. 5); What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna design, and how do they compare to existing designs? (p. 2); How can a cross-patch antenna with metasurface be designed to occupy less than 8% of a 1U CubeSat's top face while maintaining high performance? (p. 2); How can the antenna design be optimized to meet the size and performance requirements of CubeSats? (p. 10)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The proposed antenna design outperforms other designs in terms of gain, bandwidth, and size (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: 6.84% of a 1U CubeSat's top face (10 × 10 cm²) (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT 5880 (εr = 2.1, tan δ = 0.001, h = 1.5 mm) (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: High-Gain Pixel Patch Antenna Array for Miniature Wireless Communications and IoT Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To investigate pixel antenna arrays for wireless communication and IoT systems, focusing on design, analysis, and comparison with traditional designs (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a 75% reduction in patch design area and a 90% reduction in full design area (p. 14); Design and analyze pixel patch antennas for 5G and CubeSat applications (p. 1); Compare the performance of traditional and proposed pixel patch antennas (p. 1); Evaluate the performance of the proposed pixel antenna array in terms of gain and radiation pattern (p. 14)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of the proposed design in real-world 5G and CubeSat applications (p. 6); Investigate the performance of the proposed design in different environments and applications (p. 14)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the proposed pixel antenna design in small space devices and miniaturized systems (p. 14); Further testing and optimization of the proposed design for different frequency bands (p. 6)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for small, high-gain, and efficient antennas for 5G and CubeSat applications due to the rapid development of wireless technology and the downsizing of devices and satellites (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can the proposed pixel antenna design achieve miniaturization and high gain? (p. 14); How can pixel patch antennas be designed to meet the functional requirements for 5G and CubeSat applications? (p. 1); What are the performance improvements of the proposed pixel antenna compared to traditional designs? (p. 14); What are the performance metrics and design parameters of pixel patch antennas compared to traditional designs? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: Network analyzer for measuring traditional patch antenna and proposed pixel patch element structures (p. 14)
esp.domain_methodology.performance_metri: Gain, radiation pattern, design area reduction (p. 14)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Finite element method (FEM) and commercial software (Altair FEKO) (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The proposed pixel patch design area reduction is approximately 75%, and the full design area reduction is approximately 90% (p. 14)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers Duroid 6010 (εr = 10.2, tan δ = 0.0023, h = 0.635 mm) (p. 3)

gen.metadata.title: Dual-band optical imaging system-integrated patch antenna based on anisotropic fractal for earth-observation CubeSats
gen.objectives.main_objective: To propose a concept of an S-band patch antenna operating in two bands based on an anisotropic fractal with an optimal method of location for 1U-6U Earth-observation CubeSats (p. 2)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Compare the proposed antenna with existing designs (p. 7); Measure and analyze the performance metrics (p. 7); To integrate the optical (imaging device) and antenna systems into one surface (p. 2); To solve several relevant problems, including increasing the area of solar cells, thereby increasing energy security, simplifying the production of the antenna, and operating the SSC (p. 2); Model and simulate the antenna design (p. 7)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the antenna in different environmental conditions (p. 8); Investigate the impact of different substrate materials on antenna performance (p. 5); Explore the integration of the proposed antenna with other CubeSat subsystems (p. 5); Explore the integration of the antenna with other subsystems of CubeSats (p. 8)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Optimize the substrate height to improve realized gain and efficiency (p. 5); Use the proposed antenna design for 1U-6U Earth-observation CubeSats (p. 2); Integrate the proposed antenna design in future CubeSat missions (p. 8)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The limited size and communication resources of CubeSat nanosatellites require advanced solutions in this area. Efficient use of the surface area of the CubeSat is also critical. Therefore, optimization of the physical dimensions of SSC components, including antenna devices, is a relevant task (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can the physical dimensions of CubeSat components, including antenna devices, be optimized? (p. 1); What are the characteristics of a dual-band optical imaging system-integrated patch antenna based on an anisotropic fractal for Earth-observation CubeSats? (p. 1); How can a dual-band patch antenna be integrated with an optical imaging system for CubeSats? (p. 7); What are the performance characteristics of the proposed antenna compared to existing designs? (p. 7)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: Vector analyzer MS46121A, RF signal generator NI PXIe-1065, spectrum analyzer Agilent N9340B, rotating stepping system (p. 3)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 8)
esp.domain_results.bandwidth: -10 dB impedance bandwidth: 57 MHz (2423–2480 MHz) at 2.45 GHz, 33 MHz (2026–2059 MHz) at 2.04 GHz (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms other designs in terms of compactness and gain (p. 8)
esp.domain_results.gain: 4 dBi at the first resonant frequency, 2.15 dBi at the second resonant frequency (p. 8)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Apple-shaped pattern at 2.45 GHz, more directional characteristics at 2.04 GHz (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.return_loss: Much lower than -10 dB at resonant frequencies (p. 4)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Dual-band patch antenna based on anisotropic fractal (p. 1)

gen.metadata.title: Meshed Conductor and Meshed Substrate GPS L1 Band Microstrip Antenna for Cubesat Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design, simulate, and fabricate a transparent meshed conductor and meshed substrate circularly polarized GPS L1 band microstrip antenna for Cubesat applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Meet desired specifications for S11 parameter, antenna gain, bandwidth, and transparency (p. 8); Achieve circular polarization with RHCP (p. 8); Achieve a resonance frequency of 1.575 GHz (p. 3); Achieve a percentage of transparency of at least 60% (p. 3); Achieve an antenna efficiency of at least 85% (p. 3); Achieve an antenna gain of at least 5 dBi (p. 3); Achieve a bandwidth of at least 2.9% of the resonance frequency (p. 3)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the impact of different substrate materials and meshing techniques on antenna performance (p. 7); Investigation of other transparent substrate materials (p. 8)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the designed antenna in Cubesat applications for improved performance and transparency (p. 7); Further optimization of manufacturing processes to reduce error (p. 8)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Microstrip antennas are opaque, preventing solar energy from reaching the Cubesat’s solar cells, thus a transparent microstrip antenna design is required (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a transparent microstrip antenna be designed for GPS L1 band applications in Cubesats? (p. 1); How can a transparent microstrip GPS antenna be designed to meet the desired specifications? (p. 8)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: 3-D radiation pattern with maximum gain in the z-direction (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_dim: Patch: 66.4 mm × 66.4 mm, Ground: 95.3 mm × 95.3 mm (p. 4)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Transparent meshed conductor and meshed substrate circularly polarized GPS L1 band microstrip antenna (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT/duroid 5880 (εr = 2.2, tan δ = 0.0004, h = 3.175 mm) (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Coaxial probe feeding point at distance P = 22.77 mm from the left side of the patch (p. 4)

gen.metadata.title: Antena de Parche Cortocircuitado con Polarización Circular y Sentido de Giro Reconfigurable para Aplicaciones en Satélites de Reducido Tamaño
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and characterize a circular microstrip patch antenna with reconfigurable circular polarization for small satellites (CubeSat 1U) (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve an axial ratio bandwidth of 48.56 MHz (2%) at 2.44 GHz (p. 7); Achieve an axial ratio bandwidth of 48.56MHz (2%) (p. 1); Achieve a maximum gain of 6.04dBi (p. 1); Achieve a maximum gain of 6.04 dB at 2.44 GHz (p. 7); Achieve an impedance bandwidth of 27.44% (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the impact of different hybrid couplers on antenna performance (p. 8); Explore further optimization techniques to enhance performance (p. 3)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the antenna design into CubeSat 1U for improved communication performance (p. 3); Use the hybrid coupler for reconfigurable rotation direction in CubeSat applications (p. 8)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Design of a short-circuited patch antenna with circular polarization and reconfigurable rotation direction for CubeSat 1U applications (p. 6)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can the bandwidth and gain of the antenna be optimized for CubeSat applications? (p. 6); What is the impact of the hybrid coupler on the antenna's performance? (p. 6); What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna design? (p. 1); How can a circular microstrip patch antenna be designed to achieve reconfigurable circular polarization? (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Short-circuited patch antenna with circular polarization and reconfigurable rotation direction (p. 6)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: 90° hybrid coupler feeding the antenna at two points (p. 6)

gen.metadata.title: Single-feed slotted-patch antenna loaded with metasurface for CubeSat applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a low-profile, single-feed, slotted-patch antenna loaded with metasurface for S-band CubeSat applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve broadband circularly polarized radiation (p. 1); Achieve a broad bandwidth for S11 and axial ratio (p. 7); Enhance broadside gain and radiation efficiency (p. 2); Ensure high radiation efficiency and symmetric radiation pattern (p. 7)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the antenna with different substrates and in different CubeSat configurations (p. 9); Investigate the performance of the antenna in different CubeSat configurations (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the proposed antenna design in CubeSat applications for improved performance (p. 9); Use higher-quality substrates to improve radiation efficiency (p. 5)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Design challenges for CubeSat antennas include compact size, lightweight, mechanically robust structure, broadband, efficiency, stable radiation, and easy integration (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a low-profile, broadband, and circularly polarized antenna be designed for CubeSat applications? (p. 7); What are the performance enhancements of the proposed antenna compared to conventional designs? (p. 2); How can a single-feed slotted-patch antenna loaded with metasurface achieve broadband circularly polarized radiation for S-band CubeSat applications? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.performance_metri: ['Gain', 'Bandwidth', 'Return Loss', 'Axial Ratio', 'Radiation Pattern', 'Front-to-Back Ratio', 'Half-Power Beamwidths', 'Radiation Efficiency'] (p. 8)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 7)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms conventional slotted-patch antennas in bandwidth, axial ratio, and gain (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Good broadside right-hand circularly polarized (RHCP) radiation with symmetric pattern, high front-to-back ratio, and high radiation efficiency (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_dim: 0.64λmin × 0.64λmin × 0.026λmin (λmin is the free space wavelength referring to the lowest operational frequency) (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Single-feed slotted-patch antenna loaded with metasurface (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.superstrate: Metasurface of a lattice of 4× 4 periodic metal plates (p. 7)

gen.metadata.title: Design of a High-Gain X-Band Electromagnetic Band Gap Microstrip Patch Antenna for CubeSat Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a high-gain, circularly polarized X-band microstrip patch antenna (MPA) using an electromagnetic band gap (EBG) structure for CubeSat applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Ensure the antenna fits within the 10 cm × 10 cm surface area of a 3U CubeSat (p. 1); Evaluate the antenna performance with 3U CubeSat platforms (p. 16); Achieve gain enhancement using a 16-element ring of EBG structures (p. 16); Form right-hand circular polarization by etching two square slots symmetrically along the right diagonal line of the center radiator (p. 16); Integrate a single EBG ring around a single-element MPA to enhance gain and circular polarization (p. 1); Not mentioned; Maintain a simple and robust design to ensure compatibility with CubeSat standards (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Not mentioned; Investigation of other EBG structures and their impact on antenna performance (p. 1); Study different EBG and metamaterial topologies to further increase the gain (p. 16)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; Use the proposed antenna design for CubeSat applications (p. 16); Further testing and validation in real CubeSat missions (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing a high-gain, circularly polarized X-band microstrip patch antenna (MPA) for CubeSat applications, while maintaining simplicity and robustness (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What is the impact of electromagnetic band-gap (EBG) structures on the antenna's performance? (p. 16); How can the gain of a microstrip patch antenna be enhanced for CubeSat applications? (p. 16); Not mentioned; How can an electromagnetic band gap (EBG) structure be integrated into a single-element MPA to enhance gain and circular polarization while fitting within the size and weight constraints of a CubeSat? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: Anechoic chamber with a pair of X-band helical antennas (p. 12)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Time-domain solver in CST Studio Suite 2019 (p. 6)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms other designs in terms of gain, axial ratio, and bandwidth while maintaining a low profile and simple design (p. 15)
esp.domain_results.return_loss: −21.9 dB (original MPA), −18.2 dB (CP EBG MPA) at 8.483 GHz (p. 6)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_dim: 10 mm × 10 mm (center patch radiator), 10 mm × 10 mm (EBG elements), 2 mm spacing (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: Fits within 10 cm × 10 cm surface area of a 3U CubeSat (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: High-gain X-band electromagnetic band gap microstrip patch antenna (p. 1)

gen.metadata.title: Compact broadband CP corner-truncated microstrip antenna with irregularly hexagonal AMC for 2.45 GHz WLAN applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To propose a compact broadband circularly polarized (CP) corner-truncated microstrip antenna with irregularly hexagonal artificial magnetic conductor (AMC) for 2.45 GHz WLAN applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Enhance the axial ratio bandwidth (ARBW) and antenna gain using a 5 × 5 irregularly hexagonal AMC array (p. 1); Compare the proposed antenna with existing designs (p. 98); Improve the impedance bandwidth (IBW) using a tri-section meandering feedline (p. 1); Evaluate the performance of the antenna in terms of IBW, ARBW, and gain (p. 98)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the proposed antenna in other frequency bands (p. 1); Experimentally implement the antenna scheme with wireless communication systems and/or devices (p. 98)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Miniaturize the antenna scheme for more diverse applications (p. 98); Simplify the AMC array fabrication to reduce manufacturing complexity and cost (p. 98); Use the proposed antenna design for 2.45 GHz WLAN applications (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Most WLAN CP antennas have narrow impedance bandwidth, resulting in low transmission rates and failure to cover the desired frequency band. Narrow-bandwidth CP antennas often encounter installation challenges due to frequency shift, especially in small rooms with limited space where the antenna needs to be mounted on the wall (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What design modifications can enhance the performance of CP antennas in terms of gain, bandwidth, and circular polarization? (p. 1); What is the impact of the tri-section meandering feedline on impedance matching and IBW? (p. 98); How can the corner-truncated radiating microstrip patch and irregularly hexagonal AMC array be used to enhance ARBW and antenna gain? (p. 98); How can the impedance bandwidth (IBW) and axial ratio bandwidth (ARBW) of CP antennas be improved for 2.45 GHz WLAN applications? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.performance_metri: ['Gain', 'Bandwidth', 'Return Loss', 'VSWR', 'Radiation Pattern', 'Axial Ratio Bandwidth', 'HPBW', 'AR Beamwidth', 'XP Level', 'F/B Ratio'] (p. 96)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The proposed antenna achieves higher unidirectional antenna gain and wider bandwidth compared to existing designs (p. 97)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Broadband CP corner-truncated microstrip antenna with irregularly hexagonal AMC (p. 94)

gen.metadata.title: A Dual-Feed, L/S-Dual-Band-Stacked, CP Patch Antenna System for 3U CubeSat
gen.objectives.main_objective: To develop a dual-feed, L/S-dual-band-stacked, circularly polarized patch antenna system for a 3U CubeSat (p. 2)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Design and optimize the antenna and feeding network (p. 2); Maintain high stability and reliability (p. 5); Achieve a low profile of 11 mm (p. 5); Fabricate and measure the prototype (p. 3); Ensure excellent right-hand CP (RHCP) characteristics (p. 5); Obtain an HPBW of more than 80° for both bands (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Conduct further testing with the spacecraft body to validate performance (p. 4); Not mentioned
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the designed antenna system into CubeSats for high-data-rate communication (p. 4); Design the antenna in a slightly lower frequency and adjust it to the desired frequency by cutting the four stubs shorter during the experiment (p. 5)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for high-data-rate communication systems in CubeSats, which are constrained by size and weight, and the challenges of multiple-antenna design (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a dual-feed, L/S-dual-band-stacked, circularly polarized patch antenna be designed for CubeSats? (p. 2); How can a dual-feed, L/S-dual-band-stacked, CP patch antenna system be designed for 3U CubeSats? (p. 5); What are the performance metrics of the designed antenna? (p. 4)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: An in-house far-field antenna measurement system and an Agilent network analyzer (E5071C) (p. 4)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Dual-feed, L/S-dual-band-stacked, circularly polarized patch antenna (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT/duroid 5880 (εr = 2.2, tan δ = 0.0009, h = 0.787 mm) (p. 3)

gen.metadata.title: A compact tri-band omnidirectional antenna design for CubeSat applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a compact tri-band omnidirectional antenna for CubeSat applications that operates at UHF, L-band, and S-band, and can be fully enclosed within the CubeSat (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Ensure omnidirectional radiation patterns across all frequency bands (p. 1); Achieve multi-band resonance and high radiation efficiency (p. 14); Achieve stable multi-band resonance (p. 1); Compare the performance of the proposed antenna with existing CubeSat antennas (p. 14); Not mentioned; Ensure high radiation efficiency (p. 1); Ensure the antenna is fully enclosed within the CubeSat without external deployment (p. 14); Maintain a small footprint (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the antenna in different CubeSat configurations (p. 2); Explore the integration of the antenna with other CubeSat components for enhanced functionality (p. 14); Explore the use of advanced materials to further enhance antenna performance (p. 2); Not mentioned; Investigate the performance of the antenna in different environmental conditions (p. 14)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the proposed antenna design in future CubeSat missions (p. 2); Not mentioned; Utilize 3D-printed plastic materials for CubeSat construction to reduce weight and cost (p. 2); Integrate the proposed antenna design into CubeSat platforms for improved communication systems (p. 14)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The challenge of designing a compact, multi-band, omnidirectional antenna for CubeSat applications that can be fully enclosed within the CubeSat, ensuring easy integration and mechanical robustness (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What are the key design features that enable stable multi-band resonance and omnidirectional radiation patterns? (p. 1); Not mentioned; How can a compact tri-band omnidirectional antenna be designed for 1U CubeSat applications? (p. 14); How can a compact tri-band omnidirectional antenna be designed for CubeSat applications? (p. 1); What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna compared to existing designs? (p. 14)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The proposed design offers enhanced stability, compact size, and ease of deployment within a CubeSat compared to other published antenna designs (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.frequency_b: UHF (0.755 GHz), L-band (1.25 GHz), S-band (2.28 to 3.74 GHz) (p. 14)
